title-group.article-title: Deciphering the Replication-Division Coordination in E. coli: A Unified Mathematical framework for Systematic Model Comparison

abstract.p: While significant efforts have been made to model bacterial cell division, few models have incorporated DNA replication into the control of this process. To date, models that attempt to capture the coordination between replication and division cycles are based on fundamentally different assumptions, and yet conflicting results have emerged. As a result, key questions regarding how replication affects cell size at division remain unclear. To address this, we develop in a a first part, a robust mathematical framework to study models of coordination of replication and division cycles proposed in the literature. Through theoretical analysis, we highlight necessary and suffcient conditions to apply to replication-agnostic and division-agnostic models to ensure physiologically-coherent behaviors. Then, in a second part, we lead a comprehensive statistical analysis to assess the ability of the models to reproduce the division volume distribution conditioned on cell covariates. This in-depth analysis highlighted remarkable performances of a novel model, yielding promising results for future refinements toward a universal model of replication-division coordination in E. coli.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The regulation of the cell cycle in E. coli has been a subject of extensive research for over half a century. A long-standing intuition has been to view this cycle as governed by cellular clocks that reset at the beginning of each cycle, effectively "forgetting" past events [1, 2, 3]. With the advent of advanced microscopy techniques, single-cell observations have revealed significant variability in both division size and inter-generation time between individual isogenic cells, highlighting the stochastic nature of these cellular clocks [4, 5, 6, 7]. This stochasticity has challenged the deterministic approaches historically used to describe cell division in E. coli [8], necessitating alternative frameworks that better capture its regulation. In line with this intuition of resetting cellular clocks, the stochastic modeling of cell cycles has relied on Markov chain frameworks. Particularly in E. coli, division volume has been assumed to be a function of the previous division volume and independent random variables. From this approach, the adder model for cell division emerged, identifying the independent random variable not as division size (sizer model) or inter-division time (timer model), but as the volume added between birth and division [9, 10, 11, 12].

In parallel to these developments, fundamental questions have arisen regarding the control of chromosome replication initiation. Initially predicted by [13], it was later demonstrated that replication initiation events are tightly linked to the cell volume per replication origin [14, 5, 15]. Similar to division cycle modeling, replication initiation cycles have been described using a Markov chain approach, where the key variable is the volume per origin of replication at the time of initiation. An initiation adder model has then been proposed, which assumes that the independent random variable driving the Markov chain is the volume added per replication origin between successive initiation events [16, 17, 18].

Then, a fundamental challenge has been to understand how division and replication initiation cycles coordinate, particularly given that cells must ensure an exact distribution of genetic material to their progeny. This problem is especially intricate in bacteria such as E. coli, where replication cycles may undergo complex dynamics across growth conditions. Indeed, whereas under slow growth conditions, the cell replicates its chromosome between birth and division analogously to the eukaryotic cell cycle, under faster growth conditions, replication may initiate in the mother cell or in the grandmother cell. The definition of the generic C+D period, which spans from replication initiation to the division that separates the resulting sister chromosomes, has allowed to describe this phenomenon [8] (see Fig 1). When replication initiation takes place in earlier generations, C+D periods overlap, challenging our understanding of the coordination of replication and division cycles. While numerous molecular studies have provided mechanistic insights into this coordination [19, 20, 21, 22, 23], various theoretical models have been developed over the past decade to bridge between division cycles and replication cycles modeling. The objective of these models, systematically formulated as Markov chains, was to identify the key independent random variables governing this coordination. Since most of these models assume that replication initiation cycles are governed solely by the initiation adder, their main question has been to determine the extent to which replication controls division, if at all. Among these models three categories can be distinguished. The first is a replication-agnostic category of model, which states that division is independent of replication [24, 17, 25]. The second is a division agnostic category of model which states that replication is the only factor that controls division [16, 18, 26]. Finally, the third category of models assumes that division is triggered by the slowest of two independent processes, one linked to the C+D period and the other to the inter-division period. [27, 28, 29, 30, 31].

To date, the most extensive approach to test these models has been to verify whether they recover the correlations observed in the data [27, 28, 17, 18, 32, 29, 31]. While all models proposed so far have been corroborated by some correlations, some have been falsified through this approach. For example, the correlation between initiation volume and division volume has challenged the validity of replication-agnostic models [18, 31]. Another approach for testing these models has been to perturb the cell cycles. In [17], perturbations targeting replication initiation showed minimal impact on division timing, leading the authors to conclude a potential independence between these processes and to support a replication-agnostic model. Conversely, in [30] the duration of chromosome replication was increased, resulting in stronger replication-division coupling. This observation has been interpreted as proof that replication termination is a necessary preliminary step to division. Another set of experiments [33, 29] demonstrated that increasing cell width reduced the correlation between replication and division cycles, suggesting that replication alone may not su ce to trigger division, thus challenging division-agnostic models and supporting the existence of an additional parallel regulatory mechanism.

The conflicting findings from recent studies have created uncertainty in the understanding of the mechanisms of replication-division cycles coordination. While data reveal correlations between these two processes, some results challenge their true coupling [17, 32]. Moreover, although complementary results suggest that replication and division are coordinated according to a model from the third category, few results enable to fully characterize the precise mechanisms involved. Adding to this complexity is the variability in observations across growth conditions. For instance, in slow growth conditions, the division adder model fails to describe cell division [15], and replication appears to play a central role while it becomes less preponderant in fast growth conditions [30, 31]. All of these findings call for a consensus on a model capable of capturing the coordination between replication and division cycles across a wide range of growth conditions.

In this paper, we aim to bring clarifications to current uncertainties surrounding the replication-division cycles coordination through rigorous mathematical and statistical analyses of models. In a first part, we introduce a unified mathematical framework for the systematic investigation of these models and study four models: a replication-agnostic model proposed by [17]; a division-agnostic model introduced in [18]; and two third-category models, one proposed by [27]; and a second introduced here for the first time. Within this framework, we derive theoretical results and show the necessary and suffcient conditions on replication-agnostic and division-agnostic models to capture key physiological behaviors in E. coli. In a second part, we then conduct a statistical analysis that goes beyond the autocorrelation approach extensively used to date. Specifically, we compare models based on their ability to reproduce the conditional distribution of division volume, given the birth volume, initiation volume, and cell elongation rate. Through this analysis, we propose a unified comparison method that applies consistent evaluation criteria across models. Importantly, we infer the distribution of the latent variables involved in third-category models, which has never been made to date. Our results support the hypotheses underlying third-category models. Notably, our findings lend support to a new model that reconciles previously conflicting evidence regarding the interdependence between replication and division cycles. Overall, this work provides both a methodology and a model, opening new avenues for the development of a universal model of replication-division coordination.

sec.title: Unified mathematical framework for replication-division coordination
General assumptions and observed quantities
sec.p: Multiple mathematical models have been proposed in order to describe the replication-division co-ordination [16, 27, 28, 17, 18]. In order to compare and to capture the mathematical differences between these models, we introduce a general framework based on assumptions and observed quantities. This framework reproduces the monitoring of a cell lineage in a Mother Machine device [4]. At each generation, a mother cell is randomly replaced by one of its two daughters. In this framework the following assumptions are imposed:

list-item.p: The division is perfectly symmetric, i.e. the volume of the daughter cell at birth is equal to half of the volume of the mother at division.
At each replication initiation event, every origin of replication in the cell fires a new round of replication at the same time, thus doubling their number.
The origins of replication of a mother cell are equally partitioned into the daughters at division.
Over the lineage, the cell volume grows exponentially according to a growth rate function of time λ(t), that is positive and locally integrable.

sec.p: In this framework, two main quantities are studied: the cell volume, and the volume per origin of replication. According to Assumptions 1 and 4 the cell volume trajectory is continuous except at division events, when it is halved. According to Assumptions 2 and 4 the volume per origin of replication is continuous except at initiation events, when it is halved, and remains continuous at division events according to Assumptions 1 and 3. In consequence, cell volume is essentially governed by the growth rate and the division cycles while cell volume per origin is essentially governed by the growth rate and the rounds of replication initiation. The study of these quantities will be the core of the following work since their coupling will directly express the coupling between the division cycles and the replication cycles. We define (Vb(n))n≥0 the sequence of birth volumes where for all n, Vb(n) represents the birth volume of the mother cell giving rise to a daughter cell with a birth volume Vb(n+1). Identically, we define (V˜i(n))n≥0, the sequence of volumes per origin of replication immediately after initiations of replication, where for all n, the initiation event associated with V˜i(n+1) is subsequent to the initiation event associated with V˜i(n) (see Mathematical Supplementary). In a context of a dynamics over time, we additionally introduce (Tb(n))n≥0 the dates of division giving birth to the cell of volume Vb(n), and (Ti(n))n≥0, the dates at initiation of replication of the cell with a volume per origin of replication V˜i(n). The indexation of these sequences is set in such a way the sister chromosomes obtained from the replication initiated at Ti(n) are separated by the division occurring at Tb(n+1), defining the difference Tb(n+1)−Ti(n) as a C+D period for every n. From the assumptions of the framework, and based on a particular assumption over the initialization of the sequences, one can show the following expression (see Mathematical Supplementary, Lemma 1): (1)∀n≥0,Vb(n+1)=V˜i(n)exp(∫Ti(n)Tb(n+1)λ(s)ds).

As in bacteria multiple C+D periods may overlap [8], this equation provides valuable properties since it connects replication and division cycles without taking into account these overlaps. However, in order to complete the framework we add an indicator of this overlap. A good indicator is the number of origins of replication within the cells, since it directly relates to the number of ongoing (and thus overlapping) C+D period [8, 34]. In this framework, it is possible to follow both the number of replication origins at replication initiation and at birth. Here, we arbitrarily chose to monitor the number of origins of replication within a cell at birth. Let (ω(n))n≥0 be the number of origins of replication at the n-th birth. This quantity is defined on the space {2k : k ∈ ℤ}, since it is doubled at each initiation event and it is halved at each division. Note that biologically this quantity should be greater or equal to one. However, in our framework, no condition is formulated over the sequences (Ti(n))n≥0 and (Tb(n))n≥0 to prevent accumulation of division events over initiation events leading to a number of origins less that one. Within the introduced framework, one can show under the condition that (Ti(n))n≥0 is non-decreasing that this quantity is essentially linked to the sequences of dates at birth and initiation of replication (see Mathematical Supplementary, Lemma 2). For every n ≥ 0 and k ≥ –n + 1 : (2)ω(n)=2k⇔Ti(n+k−1)≤Tb(n)<Ti(n+k), (3)ω(n)≤2k⇔Tb(n)<Ti(n+k)

sec.title: Three key models from the literature
sec.p: Here we introduce and formulate three models from the literature that have drawn the most interest among the replication agnostic, division agnostic and the third category of model: the Double Independent Adders Model (DIAM), the Replication Double Adders Model (RDAM), the Concurrent Processes Model (CPM).

All these models assume consensually that replication initiation events are triggered according to an initiation adder [5, 18, 17, 16]. The initiation adder states that the initiation of replication is triggered once the cell lineage has accumulated a critical volume per origin of replication since the last initiation (Fig. 2A). This can be formulated mathematically as follows. Let (Δi(n))n≥0 be an independent and identically distributed (i.i.d.) sequence of positive random variables that admit a density fΔi, modeling the added volume per origin between the n-th and n + 1-th initiations (Table 1). The sequence (V˜i(n))n≥0 satisfies according to the initiation adder, (4)∀n≥0,2V˜i(n+1)=V˜i(n)+Δi(n).

The DIAM, proposed by [17], supposes that the cell cycles are headed by a double adder mechanism, assumed to be independent: the initiation adder and the division adder (Fig. 2B, E). This decoupling between replication and division makes (Vb(n))n≥0 and (V˜i(n))n≥0 independent processes. Similarly as the initiation adder, one may introduce (Δd(n))n≥0, the i.i.d. random variables drawn from a density fΔd, that model the added volumes over cell generations (Table 1). The couple (Vb(n),V˜i(n))n≥0 satisfies according to the DIAM: (5)(Vb(n+1)V˜i(n+1))=(2−1(Vb(n)+Δd(n))2−1(V˜i(n)+Δi(n))).

The RDAM, first proposed in Mycobacterium smegmatis [35], and then adapted in E. coli by [18], suggests that replication is central to the control of division. This model assumes an initiation-division adder such that division is triggered once the cell lineage has added a critical volume over the C+D period per origin newly formed at the initiation (hereafter referred to simply as the added volume per origin over the C+D period) (Fig. 2C, E). Let (Δid(n))n≥0 be an i.i.d. sequence of positive random variables of density fΔid that models the added volumes over the C+D periods (Table 1).
The couple (Vb(n),V˜i(n))n≥0 satisfies according to the RDAM: (6)(Vb(n+1)V˜i(n+1))=(V˜i(n)+Δid(n)2−1(V˜i(n)+Δi(n))).

The CPM proposed by [27, 28] assumes that the division is set by the slowest of two independent concurrent processes: a replication and a division-related processes [27, 29, 30]. According to this model, a cell divides after adding a critical volume since birth and completing chromosome replication and segregation. In this model, replication and segregation are supposed to follow an initiation-division timer (Fig. 2D, E). From the assumptions of the model, we can write the sequence of volume at birth (Vb(n))n≥0 as the maximum between a timer over the C+D period modeled by the i.i.d. sequence (R(n))n≥0 drawn from the density fR, and a division adder modeled by the i.i.d. sequence (Δd(n))n≥0 drawn from the density fΔd (Table 1): (7)(Vb(n+1)V˜i(n+1))=(max(V˜i(n)eΛ(n)R(n),2−1(Vb(n)+Δd(n))2−1(V˜i(n)+Δi(n))), with Λ(n):=1R(n)∫Ti(n)Ti(n)+R(n)λ(s)ds. As cell elongation has been shown to be exponential (λ constant over time) [9, 36, 37], in the following we will do the approximation that (Λ(n))n≥0 and (R(n))n≥0 are independent.

Every model introduced so far supposes (Vb(n),V˜i(n))n≥0 to be an homogeneous Markov chain, with the state of the chain at n + 1 depending on the state at n, and some i.i.d. random variables. Note that an implicit assumption is made by assuming these random variables to be identically distributed, that is, that the growth conditions are constant and that no aging process is taken into account.

Among the models considered, the DIAM and RDAM both involve two i.i.d. random variables while the CPM incorporates three i.i.d. random variables, introducing an additional degree of complexity. This added degree of complexity has challenged the comparison of these models. Specifically, one diffculty resides in inferring the distribution of the latent random variables Δd and R, in the CPM: because of the maximum operator, the measured added volumes do not necessarily correspond to observations of Δd and similarly, the measured C+D periods do not necessarily correspond to observations of R. This makes the distributions of Δd and R to not be directly deduced from observations of added volumes and C+D periods. This inability to infer the distribution of Δd and R has deeply challenged the assessment of the CPM in the literature.

sec.title: The CAM: a new model combining all three models in one
sec.p: Along to these models we introduce a novel model called the Concurrent Adders Model (CAM) that combines hypotheses assumed in the previously introduced models. The CAM is a CPM-like model that incorporates replication-based division control via an initiation-division adder as in the RDAM rather than an initiation-division timer (Fig. 2 C, E). In line with the other models, we assume that the CAM also involves an initiation adder. Let (Δd(n))n≥0 and (Δid(n))n≥0 be i.i.d. sequences of positive random variables with respective densities fΔd and fΔid (Table 1). The couple (Vb(n),V˜i(n))n≥0 satisfies according to the CAM: (8)(Vb(n+1)V˜i(n+1))=(max(V˜i(n)+Δid(n),2−1(Vb(n)+Δd(n))2−1(V˜i(n)+Δi(n))).

Similarly to the CPM, the random variables Δd and Δid are latent and thus their distribution can not be directly inferred from the observations of inter-division added volume and added volume per origin over the C+D period.

sec.title: Conditions for the validity of the DIAM and RDAM
sec.p: Stating that division and replication are decoupled processes as proposed by the DIAM, implies that the sequences (Ti(n))n≥0 and (Tb(n))n≥0 are independent and thus events such as Tb(n+1)≤Ti(n) – interpreted as negative C+D periods – could occur if no additionnal assumptions are made. Similarly, if cell division is solely regulated by replication, as proposed by the RDAM, this implies that the sequence (Tb(n))n≥0 depends exclusively on (Ti(n))n≥0 and (V˜i(n))n≥0, without explicitly considering the timing of the previous divisions. Consequently, events such as Tb(n+1)≤Tb(n), where a daughter cell divides before its mother, may not necessarily be prevented in a stochastic model with no additional assumptions. Here, we discuss that by accounting solely replication-based or division-based control of division may lead to inconsistencies without prior assumptions, and we provide necessary and suffcient conditions for the DIAM and the RDAM to avoid these irregularities within the presented framework.

Intuitively, by considering division and replication as independent processes, as proposed by the DIAM, it is likely that a cell lineage may accumulate more division events than initiation events, which would lead to the division of a cell with only one origin of replication. Such event could biologically be interpreted as leading to DNA "guillotining" [38, 39] or the formation of an anucleated cell [40]. In the context of our framework, this event corresponds to the birth of a cell with less than a half of an origin of replication which coincides with an event Tb(n+1)≤Ti(n) by (3), which corresponds to a negative C+D period. Moreover, if replication and division are decoupled one can imagine to an excessive accumulation of initiation events over division events, resulting in an infinite number of replication origins.

In this aim, one can study the long-time behavior of the DIAM, and specifically the long-time behavior of the number of origins of replication. In Proposition 1 and 2 (Mathematical Supplementary) we show that the sequences (Vb(n))n≥0 and (V˜i(n))n≥0 both converge to stationary distributions. Then, in Proposition 3 (Mathematical Supplementary), we show using (3) that thanks to these convergences in distribution, the number of origins of replication at birth converges in distribution to a limit random variable denoted by ω∞ whose distribution satisfies: (9)∀k∈ℤ,ℙ[ω∞≤2k]=ℙ[Vb∞<2k+1V˜i∞], with Vb∞ and V˜i∞ the random variables limit in distribution of (Vb(n))n≥0 and (V˜i(n))n≥0 respectively.

This first result shows that despite the decoupling of replication and division cycles, the DIAM ensures an homeostasis of the number of origins of replication. One can notice that in order to ensure a number of origin at birth greater or equal to one with probability one, the distributions of Vb∞ and V˜i∞ must satisfy ℙ[V˜i∞≤Vb∞]=1. Theorem 1 (Mathematical Supplementary) provides that this condition is verified if and only if ∃σ>0,such thatΔi<σ,andΔd>σalmost surely.

This strong result highlight the necessary and suffcient conditions to apply to the DIAM to prevent the division of a cell with one origin of replication. It is straightforward to check wether this condition is satisfied from experimental data, as this condition is not satisfied if the empirical distributions of Δd and Δi overlap. Fig. 3 shows the empirical distributions of Δd and Δi obtained in slow growth conditions in [17, 18]. As highlighted, the supports of the distributions of Δi and Δd overlap which suggests that if the cell cycles are ruled by the DIAM, in these particular conditions, there is a positive probability for a cell to divide when it has one origin of replication. From these distributions it is possible to simulate the distributions of Vb∞ and V˜i∞ and estimate this probability as it is equal to ℙ[Vb∞<V˜i∞] (see Fig. 3, Methods). Through a Monte-Carlo method, this probability has been computed to be of the order of 10–3, and 10–4 according to the data of [17] in MG1655 acetate and NCM3722 arginine respectively, and 10–3 in glycerol according to the data of [18]. In other growth conditions, this probability turns out to be highly negligible.

Here we have discussed the conditions of validity of he DIAM by assessing whether it allows division of a cell with one origin of replication. But this condition is not suffcient in order to prevent defects in genetic material partitioning. A mother cell must also have two complete chromosomes in order split equally its chromosomes into its daughters. This involves a stronger condition than the one we tested, meaning that the probability of such event is greater than the ones we computed.

Then, according to the RDAM, due to the stochastic nature of the added volume per origin over a C+D period Δid, it is possible for one C+D period to be nested within another. In other words, a C+D period may start and finish within the duration of a preceding C+D period. This scenario would imply that the (n + 1)-th birth could occur before the n-th birth, meaning that a daughter cell could divide before its mother. In order to prevent such event, the sequence of birth times, (Tb(n))n≥0, must be non-decreasing. We show in Proposition 4 that (Tb(n))n≥0 is non-decreasing if and only if ∃(σ1,σ2)∈ℝ+2\{(0,0)},such thatΔi≥σ2,andσ1≤Δid≤2σ1+σ2a.s. These conditions involve restrictions over the supports of the densities of Δi and Δid. If a daughter cell may divide before its mother with positive probability, one can estimate this probability from the observations of Δi and Δid since this probability is precisely equal to ℙ[2Δid(n+1)+Δi(n)≤Δid(n)] (see Methods). Based on datasets published in [17] and [18] we show that this probability is positive in every condition while being of the order of 10–4 for the strains MG1655 [17] and BW27378 [18] and reaching 10–8 in the strain NCM3722 [17].

sec.title: Distribution inference and systematic comparison of replication-division coordination models
sec.p: To date, the test and the comparison of replication-division coordination models has extensively been led by assessing the ability of models to reproduce correlations in the data. From these analyses of the correlations, independence between cell quantities have been concluded from zero-correlations [17, 18, 26, 32, 31]. Such deduction holds only if the variables of interest are normally distributed, however, Shapiro-Wilk normality tests indicate that division, birth, and initiation sizes deviate significantly from normal distributions (see Table S1). Then, correlation analysis gives little indication of the performance of the CPM, as the latter is based on non-linear relationships between cell variables and has so far only been studied using linear approximations [27, 28, 29, 31]. Here, we go beyond correlations and evaluate models according to their ability to reproduce division volume distribution conditioned on covariates that we have defined as the volume at birth, the volume per origin at replication initiation starting the C+D period, and the growth rate over this C+D period. To this end, we analyze 17 datasets from [17, 18, 30], which report measurements obtained using microfluidic Mother Machine devices. These datasets include information on cell length at birth and division, cell length per origin at initiation and C+D period duration. While the previous framework focused on cell volumes we hereafter use cell size as a proxy of cell volume.

sec.title: Conditional distributions of division volume
sec.p:
Here, we define the conditional distribution of division volume given birth and initiation volume and cell elongation rate over the C+D period. In the context of the framework, this coincides with the study of the distribution of 2Vb(•+1)∣Vb(•),V˜i(•),Λ(•). As shown in the Mathematical Supplementary, Proposition 5, for the different models, the conditional distribution of the volume at division 2Vb(•+1), given that Vb(•)=vb,V˜i(•)=v˜i, and Λ(•) = λ satisfies for the different models the following expressions for any v > 0:
The DIAM: (10a)p(v∣vb,v˜i,λ)=fΔd(v−vb),
The RDAM: (10b)p(v∣vb,v˜i,λ)=12fΔid(v2−v˜i),
The CPM: (10c)p(v∣vb,v˜i,λ)=fΔd(v−vb)FR(1λlog(v2v˜i))+1λvfR(1λlog(v2v˜i))FΔd(v−vb),
The CAM: (10d)p(v∣vb,v˜i,λ)=fΔd(v−vb)FΔid(v2−v˜i)+12fΔid(v2−v˜i)FΔd(v−vb), with FΔd, FΔid and FR being the cumulative distribution functions of Δd, Δid, and R respectively.

sec.title: Distribution inference of the models
sec.p: In the following we assume that the i.i.d. random variables involved in all models follow parametric densities. Specifically, we assume that these follow Generalized Gamma distributions. This three-parameters distribution gathers a broad family of unimodal probability distributions supported on R+, such as the Gamma, Weibull, Log-Normal, inverse-Gamma, inverse-Weibull distribution and others [41]. As demonstrated, this parametric distribution provides a good fit for the distribution of inter-division added volume, as previously shown in [42], as well as that of the C+D period, and the added volume per origin over the C+D period (see Figure S1). This motivates the choice of this distribution for Δd, Δid and R.

By considering a dataset (vdk,vbk,v˜ik,λk)1≤k≤N containing the measurements for N cell cycles of the division volume (2Vb(•+1)), birth volume (Vb(•)), initiation volume per origin (V˜i(•)), and cell elongation rate over the C+D period (Λ(•)), one may define the likelihood of each model for a parameter vector θ: (11)LN(θ)=∏k=1Npθ(vdk,∣vbk,v˜ik,λk), with pθ the conditional distribution of division volume defined by either (10a)–(10d), with θ containing the parameters of the distributions of the i.i.d. random variables.

The distribution parameters can be estimated by maximizing this likelihood. As already mentioned, Δd and Δid are directly observable in the DIAM and RDAM, making their distributions identifiable from the data, and the maximization of their likelihood feasible. In contrast, in the CPM and CAM, the variables Δd, R, and Δid are latent, and thus are not as trivially identifiable. In Proposition 6 (Mathematical Supplementary) we show for a general case a suffcient condition to satisfy in the data to have the identifiability of the distributions of the latent variables of the CPM and CAM. Then, the maximization of their likelihood is a challenging optimization problem. To solve this problem, we have developed an Expectation-Maximization (EM) algorithm suited for parameter estimation in models such as the CPM and CAM (see Mathematical Supplementary, Figures S2-S5).

sec.title: Comparison of conditional distributions of division size using BIC: third-category models best predict division size given cell covariates
sec.p: After finding θ* maximizing the likelihood (equation 11) for each model, one can compare these by computing the Bayesian Information Criterion (BIC) for every model defined as BIC = –log(LN(θ*))+ ρ log(N)/2, with ρ being the number of parameters (ρ = 3 for the DIAM and RDAM; ρ = 6 for the CPM and CAM). The BIC is a criterion that allows to compare models based on an approximation of their posterior probability given the data. Intuitively, a lower BIC value indicates a greater probability that a model actually explains the data [43]. Compared to the Akaike Information Criterion (AIC), the BIC has a stronger penalty term, which implies that, according to the latter criterion, the CPM and CAM are penalized more severely.

Over the 17 datasets the BIC has bas been computed for each model (Table S2). The BIC scores show that either the CPM or the CAM best predict the division size conditionally to the birth and initiation size and cell elongation rate, over a strong majority of datasets. Our results indicate that the performance of the models is growth-dependent. For instance, as shown in Fig. 4, the RDAM, the CPM and the CAM consistently exhibit lower BIC scores than the DIAM under slow growth conditions, specifically under a critical average cell elongation rate around 0.5 h–1. Given that the DIAM relies solely on birth volume, this suggests that in slow growth conditions, the initiation volume per origin brings strong advantage in predicting the volume at division. This observation coincides with latest results that argue that division is strongly controlled by replication in slow growth conditions [29, 30, 31]. Conversely, the RDAM under performs in predicting the division size in fast growth conditions, highlighting a significative role of the birth size in the division control. Then, our results suggest that replication-based control of division itself is growth-dependent. Specifically, the CAM and the RDAM, show lower BIC scores than the CPM under slow growth conditions (< 0.3 h–1). Finally, the performance of the models in division volume prediction appears to be strain dependent, as evidenced by the CAM yielding lower BIC scores than the CPM for the MG1655 strain in every growth conditions tested. Although, the RDAM and DIAM yield the best performance in the BW27783 AlaTrE and BW27783 GluCas datasets, respectively, this outcome is not supported by the AIC scores, according to which neither model achieves the best performance in any dataset (see Table S2, Figure S6).

sec.title: Comparison of initiation-division sizes joint distributions using Wasserstein distance: CAM best reconstructs initiation-division sizes dependence
sec.p: The previous results show that the CPM and the CAM are the models most likely to capture replication-division coordination. Although these models assume distinct mechanisms of replication-dependent division control the current results do not clearly favor one mechanism over the other. To address this, we compared their ability to reproduce the empirical joint distribution of initiation and division volumes which, beyond correlations, provides comprehensive information on their dependency. By simulating division sizes conditionally on measured cell covariates, one can assess which model between CPM and CAM best captures the joint distribution of initiation and division sizes. To illustrate this, in Figure 5B, we display the heat map of the experimental joint distribution of division and initiation sizes from selected datasets and their counterparts when division size is simulated by either CPM or CAM. It appears that the CAM produces distributions that are closer to the data than the CPM in the datasets a) and c). To quantify the dissimilarity between empirical joint distributions, previous studies have relied on the average of the squared difference between the theoretical joint distributions [44, 45]. However, this method requires to know the theoretical distribution of the data, and thus, often relies on regularization of the empirical data. Here we use a metric suitable for comparing 2D empirical distributions: the Wasserstein distance. Also known as the Earth Mover's Distance, this well-studied metric is solution of a transport problem that computes the minimum average distance between paired points of two empirical distributions (see Figure 5A). This metric thus precisely measures the dissimilarity between two distributions [46, 47]. By comparing experimental and simulated data, the Wasserstein distance provides a method to assess the performance of each model in reconstructing the joint distribution of initiation and division sizes. Note that intuitively, the Wasserstein distance penalizes models whose simulated data points are far from the observed data points whereas the likelihood penalizes models that assign low probability to observed data points. While these two penalty criteria may be related, these are not equivalent and thus may lead to different conclusions. To compare the CAM and the CPM, we thus computed W, the Wasserstein distance between the experimental joint distribution of division and initiation volumes (2Vb(•+1),V˜i(•)), and its counterpart when the division volume is simulated according to either the CPM or CAM (see Figure 5A). This empirical Wasserstein distance has been computed over 100 simulations according to the CPM and CAM, and the resulted collections of Wasserstein distances have been compared through Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney tests (see Materials).

As shown in Figure 5C, the CAM produces joint distributions of initiation and division sizes with significantly smaller Wasserstein distances from the experimental data than the CPM on a strong majority of datasets. These results indicate that the CAM more accurately reconstructs the joint distribution of division and initiation sizes, reflecting a better reproduction of the dependency between these two variables. By performing the same analysis with the joint distribution of division and birth sizes, we also found that the CAM more accurately reconstructs the dependency between these two variables (see Figure S9). From these results, strong arguments are provided in favor to the initiation-division adder as replication-based control of division under every growth condition.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: In this work, we proposed a rigorous framework for the study of models of the coordination between division and replication cycles. We studied four models: the DIAM, which assumes that division is solely triggered according to a division adder; the RDAM, which places replication at the center of division triggers, assuming that cells divide according to an initiation-division adder; the CPM, which assumes that division occurs once two independent processes are completed, one corresponding to a division adder and the other to a timer over the C+D period; and finally the CAM which is a novel model firstly proposed in this paper which is similar to the CPM except that it considers the replication-based control of the division as an initiation-division adder.

We studied the conditions of validity of a division agnostic and a replication agnostic models with a rigorous mathematical point of view. Confronted with the data, our results led to the conclusion that if cells follow such models, unphysiological behavior could arise with positive probability, namely, cell division with one origin of replication for the DIAM, and daughter cells dividing before their mothers for the RDAM. While computations of the probabilities of these events would classify them as rare, this shows that these models may not be robust enough to describe finely the coordination between division and replication cycles. Beyond discussing the limits of these models, our according mathematical results provide necessary and suffcient conditions over these models in order to avoid such event. Specifically in the DIAM, we provide specific assumptions regarding the supports of the densities fΔd and fΔi to ensure that the number of replication origins at birth remains greater than or equal to one with probability one. This finding suggests that independent replication and division processes could maintain the number of replication origins within physiological ranges. This may have implications in the field of synthetic biology. Recent advances in this area have focused on the development of synthetic minimal cells for industrial applications [48]. The observation that independent division and initiation adders, under certain assumptions, can lead to a balanced coupling of replication and division cycles, opens the possibility of engineering cells lacking control proteins involved in the synchronization of these processes. Considering a system where division and replication are driven solely by independent molecular networks, and meet the conditions outlined in this result, could potentially be a step toward building self replicating cells.

In this work we proposed a rigorous model comparison methodology going beyond the autocorrelation analysis extensively used to date for studying coordination between division and replication cycles. Specifically, we examined the ability of the studied models to predict division volume conditioned on birth volume, initiation volume, and elongation rate. This analysis sheds light on the role of these three covariates on the onset of division. Based on this statistical analysis we highlighted that the RDAM, which does not take into account the birth volume, and the DIAM, which does not take into account the initiation volume, predict less effectively the division size in comparison to the CAM or the CPM which take into account those two covariates in the conditional distribution of division volume. This conclusion also holds according to our Wasserstein distance analysis showing the CAM yielding to better reconstructions of joint distributions of initiation-division and birth-division joint distributions than the DIAM and RDAM (see Figure S9). Our results thus highlight that birth volume and initiation volume are both determinant covariates in cell volume at division under all growth conditions. This conclusion apparently contradicts the experimental results of

[17]. In the latter publication, an experiment showed that oscillations of DnaA gene expression lead to the oscillations of the volume at initiation while the volume at birth seems to be barely affected by these oscillations. This experiment led to the conclusion that the replication cycles and the division cycles rely on two independent mechanisms, motivating the DIAM. To settle this contradiction with our results, we simulated perturbations in the initiation adder and observe how these perturbations affects the volume at birth according to the CAM. As shown in Figure 6, our simulations exhibit similar behavior to the one observed in the experiment: the initiation volume oscillates, while the birth volume is minimally affected. Our simulations show that the CAM is consistent with the results of [17] while these have been considered as a proof of independence of the division cycles from the initiation cycles.

While we rule out the DIAM and the RDAM as universal models of replication-division co-ordination in E. coli, our results do not bring clear consensus to support either the CPM or the CAM. The CPM assumes that cells complete replication and segregation of the chromosomes after a fixed time, independent of the birth volume, the volume at replication initiation, and the cellular elongation rate. In contrast, the CAM posits that these processes conclude once the cell has added a specific volume per origin since replication initiation. Our results show that the CPM shows lower BIC scores than the CAM in fast growth conditions. However, according to the Wasserstein distance analysis, the CAM better reconstructs the dependence between division and initiation size under every growth condition. Interestingly, the RDAM also yields to smaller Wasserstein distances than the CPM between experimental and simulated joint distributions of initiation and division sizes in a majority of datasets (see Figure S8). This highlights that the CPM less effectively reproduces the dependence between division and initiation sizes than the RDAM which involves an initiation-division adder as replication-based control of division. Moreover, recent results [30, 31] have suggested a preponderant role of replication in division decision in slow growth conditions that the CAM succeeds to capture whereas the CPM fails to do so (see Figure S6). Our results thus strongly supports the initiation-division adder as replication-based control of division. Although the greater BIC values of the CAM than those of the CPM call for refinements, this suggests that the CAM is close to be a universal model for coordination of replication and division cycles in E. coli.

Whilst our results support the CAM, to our knowledge no mechanistic intuition has yet been proposed to explain the initiation-division adder [35, 18, 49]. Although it has been suggested that this process may result from a protein-counting mechanism similarly to the division adder with FtsZ [50, 17, 51, 52, 53], we propose instead that the initiation-division adder in the CAM originates from the dynamics of nucleoid formation [54, 55, 56]. The underlying hypothesis we put forward is that a cell does not only need to replicate and segregate its two chromosomes in order to divide, but also needs to add suffcient volume from initiation to make room for the sister chromosomes and for the septum formation between segregated nucleoids. It has been shown that nucleoid elongation and segregation occur at approximately the same rate as cell elongation [57, 58, 59, 60]. Assuming that septation starts once the cell has added a critical size per sister chromosome since initiation, this gives rise, in combination with the assumption of growth-balanced nucleoid elongation and segregation, to an adder behavior over the C+D period as pictured in the CAM [17]. It is plausible that whether septation is limited by an adding size or DNA replication termination depends on growth conditions and strain variability, which could explain the heterogeneity observed in the BIC comparisons between CPM and CAM. We thus conjecture that another cell variable might be at stake in order to have a full and universal picture of the coordination between replication and division cycles. Specifically, the replication termination might be a key event involved in both division control and also initiation of replication as outlined in [31], that could be included in the CAM.

sec.title: The data
sec.p: In this study the statistical analysis was conducted over the datasets collected by [17] found at https://www.cell.com/current-biology/fulltext/S0960-98221930491-9#mmc3, and by [18] found at https://github.com/guiwitz/DoubleAdderArticle/blob/master/Data_export/Fig1_2_3.csv and by [30] found at https://data.mendeley.com/datasets/hwzcywscc4/draft?a=d486eddf-c4c6-40ee-b262-913f79e5d47b.

From each datasets, four variables have been extracted: the size at division (2Vb(•+1)), the size at birth (Vb(•)), the size per origin right after the initiation of replication at the beginning of the C+D period d(V˜i(•)), and the C+D period duration (Tb(•+1)−Ti(•)). From these variables, the elongation rate over the C+D period (Λ(•)) was computed by log(Vb(•+1)/V˜i(•))/(Tb(•+1)−Ti(•)).

sec.title: Maximization of the likelihoods
sec.p: The likelihoods defined by equation (11) of the DIAM and RDAM have been maximizing using the Nelder Mead method implemented in the package optimize of SciPy in Python [61]. To maximize the likelihoods of the CPM and the CAM, an EM algorithm was implemented (see Mathematical supplementary). The maximization steps was performed, using Nelder Mead method implemented in the package optimize of SciPy and CMA-ES algorithm implemented in the package cma in Python [62]. The likelihood maximization was performed 15 times with different initial points to identify the global maximum.

sec.title: Wasserstein distances computation
sec.p: To compute the empirical Wasserstein distances used in this study, we proceeded as follow: for a given model M (chosen among DIAM, RDAM, CPM or CAM), we simulate the division sizes (VkM)1≤k≤N, conditionally to the triplet (vbk,v˜ik,λk)1≤k≤N – corresponding to an observation of (Vb(•),V˜i(•),Λ(•)). Then we compute the Wasserstein distance between the experimental joint distribution (vk, xk)k and its simulated counterpart (VkM,xk)k where (xk)k, denotes either (vbk)k,(v˜ik)k or (λk)k. By using the Python package POT [63] we computed the following Wasserstein distance: W((VM,x),(v,x)):=minσ∈ΣN1N∑k=1N(VkM−vσ(k))2+(xk−xσ(k))2,, where ΣN represents all possible permutations over a N-uplet. The parameters used in the simulations were previously estimated from the data by maximizing the likelihood defined by (11). For each dataset and each model M, we computed the Wasserstein distances for 100 simulations. From these, we compared the Wasserstein distances of the models using the Wilcoxon-Mann-Whitney test. By denoting WxM the Wasserstein distance between (VkM,xk)k and (vk, xk)k for one simulation, according the model M, we tested: ℋ0:ℙ[WxM1≤WxM2]=12ℋ1:ℙ[WxM1≤WxM2]≠12.

sec.title: Estimation of the one-origin-cell division probability in the DIAM
sec.p: For each dataset the empirical distributions of Δd and Δi have been regularized through Gaussian kernel density estimation with the package stats form SciPy of Python. Then, L = 106 cell lineages have been simulated over 100 generations. The final collection of volumes at birth (vbk)k and volumes per origin at initiation (v˜ik)k have been used to compute the probability by counting the number of couples that satisfy vb<v˜i: p^=1L2∑n=1L∑k=1L𝟙vbn<v˜ik

sec.title: Estimation of the probability of a daughter cell dividing before its mother in the RDAM
sec.p: The probability that a daughter cell divides before its mother in the RDAM has been computed from measurements of Δi and Δid, noted (Δ^ik)1≤k≤N and (Δ^idk)1≤k≤N respectively, by counting the number of times the inequality 2Δ^idj+Δ^ik<Δ^idl is true for any 1 ≥ j, k, l ≥ N. This gives the following empirical probability: p^=1N3∑j=1N∑k=1N∑l=1N𝟙2Δ^idj+Δ^ik<Δ^idl.

sec.title: Simulation of the CAM under oscillating Δi
sec.p: For this simulation, we generated birth and initiation volumes of 100 lineages, initializing each with Ti(0) distributed uniformly over [–τ, 0], where τ denotes the average generation time. To closely replicate the conditions of the DnaA underexpression experiment conducted by [17], we simulated the CAM using parameters inferred from the MG1655 Glucose dataset. The timeline was divided into intervals of normal expression and intervals of DnaA underexpression. Assuming Δi follows a Generalized Gamma distribution with parameters a priori estimated from the same dataset, we modeled the effect of DnaA underexpression by multiplying Δi(n) by a factor f > 1, when Ti(n) falls in an interval with DnaA underexpression. As in the original experiment, the perturbation and non-perturbation intervals follow one another and each last 2τ, resulting in an oscillatory pattern with a period of 4τ. In Fig 6, the simulation was performed using a scaling factor f = 1, 75.

caption.title: Summary of the studied models.
caption.p: (A) The initiation adder model assumes that the initiation of replication event setting the initiation volume per origin V˜i(n+1) is triggered once the cell has added a volume per origin of replication Δi(n) assumed to be independent of V˜i(n), since the last initiation event. (B) The division adder assumes that the division occurring at Tb(n+1) is set once the cell has added a volume Δd(n) since birth, assumed to be independent to Vb(n). (C) The initiation-division adder assumes that the division occurring at Tb(n+1) is set once the cell has added a volume per origin Δid(n) since the beginning of the C+D period, assumed to be independent to V˜i(n). (D) The initiation-division timer assumes that the division occurring at Tb(n+1) is set after an amount of time Rn after the beginning of the C+D period, assumed to be independent to V˜i(n). Table (E) displays the control mechanisms of replication cycles and division cycles for each model studied in this work.
